ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Great proficiency in ASL and expanded knowledge about Deaf culture

We learned more about the different types of classifiers and how theyre used; what non-manual markers are and how to use those; better ways of transitioning between times, locations, and topics; more vocabulary to describe family, location, history, and migration; and how to synthesize all of these things to tell more engaging ASL narratives. This built upon past ASL I and II's coverage of literary devices commonly used in Deaf storytelling, like parallel structures, making signing space, role-shifting, and similes. Near the end of the semester, we also learned about the histories of Deaf theater and cinema.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Great course, the professor is unbelievably amazing, and you learn so much over the course of the semester. No weaknesses.

Especially if Prof. Conlin is teaching it, this class is a really great way of strengthening your ASL and engaging more with Deaf history and the importance of shared narratives in Deaf culture. There is a lot of performing and presenting in front of the class, including one class involving ASL improv theater, so be aware of that when going in.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: YES. If you need a language requirement, immediately register. If you don't need a language credit, but have room for a credit, immediately register. It is amazing. ASL is such an accessible language, the professors are amazing, and the workload isnt too bad.

Absolutely, especially if they can get a section with Prof. Conlin, who's an amazing and encouraging instructor. However, students with bad stage fright might have a more difficult time with the in-class performances and presentations.

I would highly recommend L3 with Professor Conlin. She's an incredibly kind, understanding and engaging teacher with amazing amounts of knowledge. She makes an effort to connect with each of her students. I was genuinely excited to learn from her every day! If you've taken L1 and L2, the workload and expectations are similar (maybe slightly higher in L3). It was also the semester that I feel I learned the most!
